content: On the nLab page for the Grothendieck construction, it's stated ∫F\int F∫F is an oplax colimit. The way it is phrased makes me think it refers to the covariant Grothendieck construction. Is there a similar characterization for the contravariant Grothendieck construction? Is it just the lax colimit of a contravariant pseudofunctor FFF?

You get the contravariant one from the covariant one by applying −op-^\mathrm{op}−op on Cat\mathbf{Cat}Cat.

You start from F:C→CatF: C \to \mathbf{Cat}F:C→Cat. First you obtain the covariant construction ∫F\int F∫F as an oplax colimit, i.e. a universal lax cone under FFF with tip ∫F\int F∫F. Applying the involution −op-^\mathrm{op}−op sends this to a universal oplax cone under FopF^\mathrm{op}Fop (the “pointwise opposite” of FFF) with tip (∫F)op(\int F)^\mathrm{op}(∫F)op, which is the contravariant Grothendieck construction. So the latter should be the lax colimit of the pointwise opposite of FFF.

Which is different from ∫(Fpop)\int (F^\mathrm{pop})∫(Fpop).
You can see that the latter is the oplax colimit of FpopF^\mathrm{pop}Fpop, while earlier I characterised ∫opF\int_\mathrm{op} F∫op​F as its lax colimit.

I think I'm challenging your claim that (∫F)op=∫opF(\int F)^{op} = \int_{op} F(∫F)op=∫op​F. In the first category, morphisms (A,A′)→(B,B′)(A,A') \to (B,B')(A,A′)→(B,B′) are given by arrows f:B→Af : B \to Af:B→A and f′:F(f)(B′)→A′f' : F(f)(B') \to A'f′:F(f)(B′)→A′. In the second category, morphisms (A,A′)→(B,B′)(A,A') \to (B,B')(A,A′)→(B,B′) are given by arrows f:B→Af : B \to Af:B→A and f′:A′→F(f)(B′)f' : A' \to F(f)(B')f′:A′→F(f)(B′).
If you flip FFF pointwise, then the latter arrow lives in F(A)opF(A)^{op}F(A)op, and thereby corresponds to an arrow F(f)(B′)→A′F(f)(B') \to A'F(f)(B′)→A′ in F(A)F(A)F(A).

Your suggestion is valuable anyway: opopop exchanges lax and oplax co/limits, so if ∫F\int F∫F is the oplax colimit of FFF then (∫F)op(\int F)^{op}(∫F)op has to be the lax colimit. But then (∫F)op=∫opFpop(\int F)^{op} = \int_{op} F^{pop}(∫F)op=∫op​Fpop. So the lax colimit of FFF is presented by the contravariant Grothendieck construction of its pointwise opposite.
Now ∫opF=(∫Fpop)op\int_{op} F = (\int F^{pop})^{op}∫op​F=(∫Fpop)op. The latter is the lax colimit of FpopF^{pop}Fpop, hence ∫opF\int_{op} F∫op​F presents the lax colimit of its pointwise opposite.

@_Matteo Capucci (he/him)|275932 said:

What do you mean by equally good?

I mean that the question “which one is the (contravariant) Grothendieck construction” seems equally unimportant to me as “is iii or −i-i−i the root of -1”. The contravariant Grothendieck construction is, in its essence, a way of turning a pseudofunctor C→CatC \to \mathbf{Cat}C→Cat into a Grothendieck fibration over CopC^\mathrm{op}Cop. Since there is an involutive automorphism on pseudofunctors C→CatC \to \mathbf{Cat}C→Cat, the “pointwise opposite”, this way “is” two ways, related by the automorphism, and privileging one is only a matter of convenience. I have found (∫F)op(\int F)^\mathrm{op}(∫F)op more useful in my own work so I tend to think of it as “the” one but that's completely arbitrary.

There's a similar argument to be made about whether the covariant or the contravariant Grothendieck construction are “the Grothendieck construction”... really it's all one thing, with a Z/2Z×Z/2Z\mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z} \times \mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}Z/2Z×Z/2Z group of automorphisms :)

It seems sensible to set things up to be "unital" in the sense that if C=1C = 1C=1, then both Grothendieck constructions applied to F:1→CatF : 1 \to \mathrm{Cat}F:1→Cat produce the original category F(∗)F(*)F(∗), not its opposite; particularly if one wants the construction to be given by a lax (or oplax) colimit.
If I'm not mistaken, only one of the choices being discussed here has that property.
